articles.headline: Senate Inquiry Faults Hedge Funds’ Tax Strategy
articles.snippet: Hedge funds have claimed billions of dollars in tax savings through complex financial structures created by Barclays and Deutsche Bank, a Senate inquiry has found.
articles.abstract: Hedge funds have claimed billions of dollars in tax savings through complex financial structures created by Barclays and Deutsche Bank, a Senate inquiry has found.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:27 p.m. | A Senate investigation has found that hedge funds — in particular, James H. Simons’ Renaissance Technologies — used complex financial structures to claim billions of dollars in tax savings.

articles.headline: Netflix, Growing, Envisions Expansion Abroad
articles.snippet: The company reported its business grew in the second quarter thanks to international customers and little adverse effect from an announced price increase.
articles.abstract: The company reported its business grew in the second quarter thanks to international customers and little adverse effect from an announced price increase.
articles.lead_paragraph: Netflix made its first splash in original programming with “House of Cards,” the political drama focused on Washington. Next up, “House of Versailles”?

articles.headline: After Malaysia Airlines Crashes, the Payments Are Piling Up for Air Insurers
articles.snippet: The carrier’s two crashes in less than five months could carry a high cost for the aviation insurance industry, especially as its policy lacked a standard limiting clause.
articles.abstract: The carrier’s two crashes in less than five months could carry a high cost for the aviation insurance industry, especially as its policy lacked a standard limiting clause.
articles.lead_paragraph: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — Malaysia Airlines’ two crashes in less than five months are sending tremors through the aviation insurance market — not least because the carrier’s $2.25 billion overall liability policy is mysteriously missing a standard phrase that usually limits insurers’ payments for search-and-rescue costs.

articles.headline: Investors to Directors, ‘Can We Talk?’
articles.snippet: Boards have long shunned speaking with investors for several reasons, including concern about accidentally disclosing sensitive information.
articles.abstract: Boards have long shunned speaking with investors for several reasons, including concern about accidentally disclosing sensitive information.
articles.lead_paragraph: What if lawmakers never spoke to their constituents?

articles.headline: After 128 Years of Rolling Them, Tampa Is Close to No Cigars
articles.snippet: New regulations could lead to the closing of the last cigar factory in the historic Ybor City, a Tampa neighborhood that was once home to scores of cigar makers.
articles.abstract: New regulations could lead to the closing of the last cigar factory in the historic Ybor City, a Tampa neighborhood that was once home to scores of cigar makers.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Some unforgettable places waft into memory on a scent. For Floridians, it may be the sweetness of mangoes in Miami, the salt-sprinkled air of the Keys, the pungency of the Everglades.

articles.headline: Cash Crops With Dividends: Financiers Transforming Strawberries Into Securities
articles.snippet: With its steady income stream, farmland is proving to be a ripe offering for sophisticated investors.
articles.abstract: With its steady income stream, farmland is proving to be a ripe offering for sophisticated investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: His boots were caked with mud when Thomas S. T. Gimbel, a longtime hedge fund executive, slipped in a strawberry patch. It was the plumpness of a strawberry that had distracted him.

articles.headline: Journey Home Finally Begins for the Victims of Malaysia Airlines Flight
articles.snippet: The train bearing the bodies of the victims of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 finally began its long journey to get them out of Ukraine’s war-torn badlands and closer to home.
articles.abstract: The train bearing the bodies of the victims of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 finally began its long journey to get them out of Ukraine’s war-torn badlands and closer to home.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOREZ, Ukraine — In the end, they were sent off alone, without ceremony, well-wishers or anyone much beyond a handful of armed rebels on the platform.
articles.byline: By Sabrina Tavernise and Noah Sneider

articles.headline: 2 Banks Forged in Crisis, CIT and OneWest, Are Set to Merge, to a Big Payoff
articles.snippet: The CIT Group, which is run by John A. Thain, has agreed to acquire the parent company of OneWest Bank for $3.4 billion in cash and stock.
articles.abstract: The CIT Group, which is run by John A. Thain, has agreed to acquire the parent company of OneWest Bank for $3.4 billion in cash and stock.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:05 p.m. | For some, the financial crisis was very, very good.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: New Questions on Health Law as Rulings on Subsidies Differ
articles.snippet: One federal appeals court panel ruled that the federal government could not subsidize coverage bought by people on the federal insurance exchange. Another said the opposite.
articles.abstract: One federal appeals court panel ruled that the federal government could not subsidize coverage bought by people on the federal insurance exchange. Another said the opposite.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two federal appeals court panels issued conflicting rulings Tuesday on whether the government could subsidize health insurance premiums for millions of Americans, raising yet more questions about the future of the health care law four years after it was signed by President Obama.

articles.headline: Miami Diner, Pioneer in City’s Race Relations, Serves Last Cup
articles.snippet: The owner of Jumbo’s hired and served blacks when few white-owned restaurants in Miami did. Now, he is forced to close after decades of white flight, riots and hurricanes.
articles.abstract: The owner of Jumbo’s hired and served blacks when few white-owned restaurants in Miami did. Now, he is forced to close after decades of white flight, riots and hurricanes.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — While the line of white customers used to snake out the door at Jumbo’s, a 24-hour diner here, black people were served fried shrimp from a takeout window in the back or crammed into a small table in a darkened storage room.
